Dear Thomas, 

Thank you for submitting Robert Frost Helps Me Talk to My Father to Bartleby Snopes. We appreciate the chance to read your work. Unfortunately, this piece is not for us. We tend to prefer stories with more dramatic tension and more fully developed characters. This is more of anecdote. It needs more substance to carry the narrative, such as more demonstrated tension and conflict between the father and son and clarification about their relationship. 

Good luck with this one elsewhere. Feel free to try us again in the future with something new, but please wait at least one month before submitting again. 

Sincerely, 
The Editors 
Bartleby Snopes 
www.bartlebysnopes.com

You can go here to view the submission:
http://bartlebysnopes.submittable.com/user/submissions/3860190

Paper only:
	ﾥ	Typed, double-spaced, on one of 8.5ￓ x 11ￓ paper
	ﾥ	Include cover letter (one page limit): name, address, phone number, email address, title of piece, and approximate word count
	ﾥ	8,000 word limit for general submissions
	ﾥ	Do not send disks or electronic files
	ﾥ	Multiple submissions not accepted from individual authors (non-contest submissions only)
	ﾥ	Simultaneous submissions require immediate notification to Fourth Genre if accepted elsewhere

They respond via email. Do not send SASE.

Comments from Randall Brown: 

Thanks for all the kind words. My only suggestion is (perhaps) to add
something more about the process of submissions than the "numbers." For
example, those fifty pieces have been, for the most part, being written,
workshopped, revised, tweaked for usually 6 months to a year before they
are being submitted. Also, those 250 journals are all journals I have some
familiarity with‹by knowing their editor(s), their published authors,
and/or editors. So I think the Big Leagues is more than getting up to bat
more often; it is also about having better preparation, scouting, and the
like.

PS Stories Write-a-Thon

We think the three poets we've had the pleasure of featuring all know how to make a damn good sandwich, different in their own way, but with a common attraction to every day life and its whimsy, sometimes tragedy, despair, hope. They've set out on the journey to, in the words of Raymond Carver, "endow those things--a chair, a window curtain, a fork, a stone, a woman's earring--with immense, even startling power."

We came upon one of Thomas Jay Rush's short stories in which the unlikely word "peas" (empowered by just the right punctuation) gave this startling effect. His poems deal similarly with everyday things and feelings in a language that is non-ornamental but that still (maybe because of this) direct our attention elsewhere, outside the poem, toward some mystery or other.

http://kitchenpoet.blogspot.com/2011_01_01_archive.html

We came upon one of Thomas Jay Rush's short stories in which the unlikely word "peas" (empowered by just the right punctuation) gave this startling effect. His poems deal similarly with everyday things and feelings in a language that is non-ornamental but that still (maybe because of this) direct our attention elsewhere, outside the poem, toward some mystery or other.
